articles.description: A new way of measuring structures deep inside Earth has highlighted numerous previously unknown blobs within our planet's mantle. These anomalies are surprisingly similar to sunken chunks of Earth's crust but appear in seemingly impossible places.
articles.content:
Potential patches of Earth's ancient crust, sometimes called "sunken worlds," may have just been discovered deep within the mantle, thanks to a new way of mapping the inside of our planet
. However,… [+4350 chars]

articles.author: Paul Sutter
articles.title: Something invisible and 'fuzzy' may lurk at the Milky Way's center, new research suggests - Livescience.com
articles.description: The cores of galaxies may not be made of what we thought, new research suggests — they could hold one giant, invisible star made of mysterious "fuzzy" matter.
articles.content:
Galaxies may be anchored to giant "dark stars" — clumps of invisible matter sitting at their cores, new research suggests.
Although astronomers have an abundance of evidence that most of the mass in… [+3483 chars]

articles.title: Life in the '90s: Barrier Reef biodiversity has 'shifted significantly' - Oceanographic Magazine
articles.description: Fish communities living on the Great Barrier Reef today are "substantially different" to those that lived there in the 1990s, new study finds
articles.content: Fish communities living on the Great Barrier Reef today are substantially different to those that inhabited the coral reef ecosystem – the largest in the world – back in the 1990s, a new study lookin… [+3140 chars]

articles.author: Harry Baker
articles.title: Earth from space: Svalbard's radioactive 'Bear Island' surrounded by rare cloud swirls and a giant algal bloom - Livescience.com
articles.description: A 2023 satellite image captured a pair of peculiar phenomena painting parallel swirls in the sea and sky around Norway's Bear Island, which is surrounded by extremely radioactive waters left behind by a doomed Soviet submarine.
articles.content:
Where is it? Bear Island, Svalbard [74.43137835, 19.058443166]
What's in the photo? Atmospheric vortices in the clouds and a swirling algal bloom in the ocean
Which satellite took the photo? NASA A… [+3496 chars]

articles.title: Spiky fossils Punk and Emo change our understanding of molluscan evolution - Nature.com
articles.description: Two fossils from about 430 million years ago suggest early worm-like molluscs were more diverse than the group is today.
